# My Note Server

A **simple**, **self-hosted** note-taking and **slide-making** solution with first-class support for markdown, math and hand-drawn figures.
This demo does not have any server-side capability, and only serves to demonstrate the editor on a sample buffer.

---

# Features

* Notes are stored as plain markdown files in a single directory of your choosing. No databases or metadata.
  * This includes images; they are stored as raw svg tags in the markdown file (and automatically collapsed in the editor)
* Typed content comes _first_, all based on Markdown with first-class support for math
  * Automatically configured snippet completion for most built-in LaTeX commands, **and** user-added macros.
  * Configure your own MathJax macros, as well as arbitrary vscode-style snippet completions, a few of which come included. The display math environment below was autocompleted from typing `@disp` $\to$ `tab`, and uses custom macros.
    $$
    \setbuilder{a \in \qq}{\what{a} \geq 0} = \inflim{n} \int_a^b f(x) \; dx = \infsum{n}{0}{\infty} a_n \, g(n)
    $$
* Some useful markdown extensions are automatically included, such as [markdown-it-attrs](https://github.com/arve0/markdown-it-attrs), allowing advanced formatting capability: _style this em tag_{style="color: red;"}
* See [the docs](https://github.com/cemulate/mynoteserver?tab=readme-ov-file#my-note-server) for more.

---

# Figures

You can augment your primary typed note content with hand-drawn figures. 
* Press `ctrl+space` or the image button in the toolbar to instantly insert a sketch.
* Paste an image from the clipboard to draw over it.

Images are stored as raw svg tags in the markdown file, and automatically collapsed in the editor. 
Edit an existing image by performing the same action as above with the cursor on the image tag.

575.44,543.60 575.56,543.48 575.69,543.39 575.85,543.33 576.01,543.32 576.17,543.34 576.33,543.40 " class="mns"></path></svg>

---

# Slides

One line of text changes your file from being rendered as a document to being rendered as a [Reveal.js presentation](https://revealjs.com/).
Simply start the file with `---` (normally a horizontal rule), and further use `---` as the boundary between slides. Try it now to see this document as a presentation!

#### Fragmented mode

In presentation mode, toggling the `Fragmented` button on the tool bar will **automatically** add Reveal.js's `fragment` class to all top-level block elements in the presentation, making the presentation **automatically proceed step-by-step**.

---

# Limited offline support

Though the app doesn't feature full offline support (in the vein of, e.g., Google docs), the editor still fully works offline. In offline mode (or any time), you can create and edit buffers that are saved in the browser's local storage by starting their name with `@`.

# Other features

* The editor is served under `/app`, but you can access
  * A directory listing of your notes at `/notes`
  * A (static) rendered view of any note or presentation at `/notes/...path`.
  * This feature can be used to print/export a Reveal.js presentation, [per the reveal.js docs](https://revealjs.com/pdf-export/).
* QOL features expected of a markdown editor
  * Basic synchronization between source and rendered view; clicking on rendered content will go to that area of the source.
  * Only content that was changed is re-rendered.
* Dark mode support

# FAQ

* _Can't emacs do this?_ Probably, yes.
* _Can't [other popular markdown note-taking solution] do all this and more?_
  * Mostly yes, but not that I'm aware of for some particular features.
* _Why did you make this?_
  * Because I was put off by the relative complexity, learning curve, ability to self-host, or the lack of very particular features or customization ability of those other solutions (and I don't want to learn emacs). I worked on it in small bits over a few years and eventually it became a fun project to add more features.
